docs.lead_paragraph: Children who live in the poorest neighborhoods of cities tend to face the biggest risk of being hit by cars, according to two new studies that independently looked at the problem in Britain and the United States. The two studies concluded that a combination of factors helped to raise the dangers faced by children in poor urban areas. Among them are congestion, lack of safe places to play, poorly maintained roads and lax enforcement of traffic laws.
docs.abstract: Study released by Britain's Imperial College Center for Transport Studies concludes that children living in poorest urban areas are more than three times as likely to be struck by cars or trucks as those living in most affluent areas; American study,led by Yale School of Medicine researcher Dr Thomas Renshaw and published in Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery, finds safety measures and programs instituted in New Haven, Conn, have resulted in sharp decline in number of children stuck by cars and trucks between 1993 and 1999; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Children who live in the poorest neighborhoods of cities tend to face the biggest risk of being hit by cars, according to two new studies that independently looked at the problem in Britain and the United States.    The two studies concluded that a...

docs.lead_paragraph: What maketh the man? Is it chromosomes? Or is it genitalia? Or, to borrow from Polonius, is it clothes? In her new book, ''How Sex Changed: A History of Transsexuality in the United States,'' Dr. Joanne Meyerowitz, a professor of history at Indiana University and the editor of The Journal of American History, examines changing definitions of gender through the prism of transsexuality, that most mysterious of conditions in which a person is born with normal chromosomes and hormones for one sex but is convinced that he or she is a member of the other.

headline.main: On Being Male, Female, Neither or Both

docs.abstract: Article discusses several new books on subject of transgender sexuality; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: External sounds that disrupt your concentration and your sleep are bad enough. But in most cases they are either short-lived or there is some way to escape them or shut them out. But when the noise is inside your head and continuous or nearly so, it could literally drive you crazy. Such is the case with a disorder called tinnitus (tin-EYE-tus and TIN-uh-tus are correct), a hissing, roaring or ringing of varying volume in one or both ears or in the head that may be steady or intermittent but persistent.

headline.main: New Hopes for Quieting the Roaring in the Ear

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on tinnitus, its causes and treatment; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Giving recently divorced mothers training in child-rearing skills cut in half the mental disorders found six years later among their adolescent children in comparison with children in a similar group, a new study is reporting. The children whose mothers received training also reported lower levels of drug abuse and less sexual activity. But no additional benefit was found among families whose children were given training in coping skills as well.

headline.main: Moms Go to Class but Kids Gain

docs.abstract: Study conducted by Arizona State University psychologist Dr Sharlene Wolchik, published in October 16 issue of Journal of American Medical Assn, finds that children whose divorced mothers received child-rearing training had 50 percent fewer mental disorders, lower levels of drug abuse and less sexual activity six years later; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Giving recently divorced mothers training in child-rearing skills cut in half the mental disorders found six years later among their adolescent children in comparison with children in a similar group, a new study is reporting.    The children whose...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who chew garlic tablets to help their hearts while avoiding the smell may be helping nothing at all. A study being published online today showed that 7 of 14 garlic supplements contained less of garlic's active ingredient than researchers called necessary for a therapeutic effect. The study was conducted by ConsumerLab.com, a company that tests dietary supplements. Dr. Tod Cooperman, ConsumerLab's president, said the products varied widely in their strength.
docs.abstract: Study conducted by ConsumerLab.com, which will be published online, shows that 7 of 14 garlic supplements tested contain less of garlic's active ingredient than researchers deem necessary to lower cholesterol levels; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People hoping to stay sharp as they age often turn to crossword puzzles, math problems and other demanding intellectual pursuits. But is all that really necessary?

headline.main: Social Whirl May Help Keep the Mind Dancing

docs.abstract: Article on new studies conducted by psychologists at University of Michigan and University of Denver concluding that ordinary day-to-day social activities are at least as useful as more formal intellectual activities in preserving mental acuity as one ages (M)
docs.snippet: People hoping to stay sharp as they age often turn to crossword puzzles, math problems and other demanding intellectual pursuits.    But is all that really necessary?

docs.lead_paragraph: Antibacterial soap is no better than regular soap at keeping hands free of bacteria, according to a study presented last week. But what does seem to have a striking effect on cleanliness, the study's author said, is the feeling that somebody is keeping track of how well people scrub. In the study, 224 parents had their hands checked for bacteria levels, and then they were given free soap for a year. Half received regular soap and half received soap marketed as antibacterial or antimicrobial. The soap was delivered monthly.
docs.abstract: Columbia University School of Nursing researcher Dr Elaine Larson, addressing annual meeting of Infectious Disease Society of America in Chicago, says study shows that antibacterial soap is no better than regular soap at keeping hands free of bacteria; also finds that bacteria levels fall sharply in people who are given free soap, either regular or those marketed as antibacterial or antimicrobial (M)
docs.snippet: Antibacterial soap is no better than regular soap at keeping hands free of bacteria, according to a study presented last week. But what does seem to have a striking effect on cleanliness, the study's author said, is the feeling that somebody is...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas E. Steinemann, a Cleveland ophthalmologist, has seen his fair share of patients with tragic eye disorders. But few have been sadder, he said, than the teenager whose vision was permanently damaged last year by a pair of contact lenses she wore solely to change the color of her eyes. ''Her normal eye color is brown,'' Dr. Steinemann said. ''She wanted green eyes to coordinate with an outfit.''
docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration, conducting investigation following complaint by Cleveland ophthalmologist Dr Thomas E Steinemann, warns consumers against wearing decorative contact lenses without proper fitting and a valid prescription; experts say preteens and teenagers are buying lenses in novelty shops and via Internet without proper instruction on how to insert and care for them; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than 1 percent of U.S. agricultural land is organic, but that is changing fast. More than 2.3 million acres were farmed in 2001 -- two-and-a-half times as much as in 1995. For the first time, ''organic'' foods have to meet consistent standards, the government announced last week. Here are some of the rules farmers and processors must follow.

headline.main: How Foods Earn the New Organic Seal

docs.abstract: Drawing shows some of new rules US government has issued which farmers and processors must follow to have food labeled organic (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The woman was 93 and still tap-dancing. In her 20's, she performed for a professional touring dance company. In her 30's and 40's, she taught dance at Juilliard. For the 50 years since then, she had tapped eagerly at amateur shows and recitals. When she arrived at my office complaining of weakness and pain in her arms and legs, her only concern was that she would no longer be able to tap out a rhythm.

headline.main: When Doctors Say Don't and the Patient Says Do

docs.abstract: Marc Siegel Cases article recounts case in which 93-year-old tap dancer convinced him to approve spinal surgery to correct bulging and inflammed disk (M)
